content: The Act may be cited as the "Melanie Blocker-Stokes Postpartum Depression Research and Care Act". Postpartum depression is a mood disorder that affects many women during and after pregnancy. It can be categorized into three subgroups: "baby blues", postpartum mood and anxiety disorders, and postpartum psychosis. "Baby blues" is characterized by mood swings, feeling overwhelmed, tearfulness, irritability, poor sleep, mood changes, and vulnerability. Postpartum mood and anxiety disorders include symptoms like worsening baby blues, postpartum psychosis involves losing touch with reality, distorted thinking, and hallucinations. Around 400,000 women experience postpartum mood changes annually, with baby blues affecting up to 80% of new mothers. Postpartum depression is treatable if promptly diagnosed. Postpartum depression, if promptly diagnosed, can be treated with a personalized regimen of care including social support, therapy, medication, and hospitalization. However, it often goes undiagnosed or untreated due to social stigma, the myth of motherhood, self-diagnosis challenges, shame, lack of understanding, and economic pressures. Untreated postpartum depression can lead to further mental health issues, substance abuse, job loss, divorce, social alienation, and self-destructive behavior. Untreated postpartum depression can lead to social alienation, self-destructive behavior, and impact society through infant development, child abuse, neglect, or family disruption. TITLE I--RESEARCH ON POSTPARTUM DEPRESSION AND PSYCHOSIS: Expansion and intensification of activities. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, through the National Institutes of Health, is encouraged to continue research on postpartum depression and psychosis, coordinating with other institutes to expand understanding and find a cure. Activities under this subsection aim to expand understanding and find a cure for postpartum conditions through basic research, epidemiological studies, improved screening techniques, clinical research for new treatments, and information/education programs for healthcare professionals and the public. The National Institutes of Health and Health Resources and Services Administration are encouraged to conduct a national public awareness campaign on postpartum depression and psychosis, including public service announcements. Additionally, there will be biennial reporting on depression and a longitudinal study on the mental health consequences of resolving a pregnancy. The Director of the Institute may conduct a longitudinal study on the mental health consequences for women of resolving a pregnancy in various ways, including carrying to term, adoption, miscarriage, and abortion. Reports on the findings should be submitted to Congress periodically. Establishment of a program of grants for delivery of services regarding postpartum depression and psychosis. The Secretary of Health and Human Services should make grants for projects to provide essential services for individuals with postpartum depression or psychosis and their families. Grants can be given to public or nonprofit entities, including hospitals, community organizations, and health centers. The Secretary of Health and Human Services should ensure that projects provide services for postpartum conditions, including outpatient and inpatient care management services for individuals and their families. Activities may include screening, treatment, and support services to improve the quality and availability of healthcare. The Secretary of Health and Human Services should integrate the program for postpartum conditions with other grant programs, including those under the Public Health Service Act, to provide a range of health care and support services for individuals and their families. SEC. 202. CERTAIN REQUIREMENTS. A grant under section 201 requires the applicant to agree to specific conditions: 1) Use no more than 5% for administrative purposes, 2) Supplement, not replace, other funds for postpartum treatment, 3) Follow limitations on charges set by the Secretary, and 4) Not use the grant for services already covered under section 201(a). The applicant receiving a grant under section 201 must adhere to specific conditions, including limiting administrative expenses to 5%, supplementing rather than replacing postpartum treatment funds, following charge limitations set by the Secretary, and not using the grant for services already covered under section 201(a). Additionally, the applicant must post notices at service sites informing individuals of any applicable Federal policies regarding charges for services. The Secretary can offer technical assistance to help entities comply with the requirements of this title to qualify for grants under section 201. Authorization of appropriations includes $3,000,000 for fiscal year 2008 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2009 and 2010.
